repository.corpname: Princeton University. Library. Dept. of Rare Books and Special Collections

did.abstract: Toni Morrison (born Chloe Ardelia Wofford, 1931) is a Nobel prize-winning American author, editor, and Professor Emeritus at Princeton University. The material described in this finding aid consists of manuscripts, drafts, galleys, and proofs of Morrison's novels; personal correspondence; editorial files relating to Morrison's work at Random House and later publication of two posthumous works by Toni Cade Bambara; and academic and teaching files, particularly pertaining to SUNY Albany and Princeton University. Other material from the collection, including drafts of non-fiction, theatrical, and children's literature, office working files, published books, press clippings, photographs, audiovisual materials, awards and memorabilia will be added as processing is completed.
did.physloc: This collection is stored partially onsite at Firestone Library and partially offsite (boxes 103-114) at the ReCAP facility. Boxes 1-11; 13-19; 22-29; 32-47; 50-56; 59-62; and 64-66 are stored in a special vault facilities in Firestone Library.

bioghist.p: Toni Morrison was born Chloe Ardelia Wofford in Lorain, Ohio in 1931. She attended Howard University, graduating in 1953 with a degree in English, then received an MA in literature from Cornell University in 1955.

After a brief teaching stint at Texas Southern University, Morrison returned to teach at Howard in 1957. There, she married architect Harold Morrison, with whom she had two sons, Harold Ford Morrison (born 1961) and Slade Kevin Morrison (1964-2010). The two divorced around the time of Slade’s birth, after which Morrison began working as a textbook editor for a division of Random House based in Syracuse, NY. In 1967, Morrison was promoted to senior editor and moved to New York City, where she worked with a number of emerging influential African-American writers, including Toni Cade Bambara, Angela Davis, Henry Dumas, and Gayl Jones, in addition to editing The Black Book (1974), a compilation of African-American historical documents.

Morrison’s first novel, The Bluest Eye, was published in 1970. She has published a total of eleven novels to date, winning numerous literary and cultural awards including the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction for Beloved in 1988, the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1993, the National Humanities Medal in 2000, and the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2012. In addition to her novels, Morrison has written non-fiction, poetry, children’s literature (in collaboration with her son Slade), and dramatic works.

In 1983, she left her position at Random House to concentrate on writing and teaching, serving as the Albert Schweitzer Professor of the Humanities at SUNY Albany from 1984-1989, then the Robert E. Goheen Professor in the Council of the Humanities at Princeton University until her retirement in 2006. During this time, she taught classes in creative writing, African-American studies, and, at Princeton, developed the interdisciplinary Atelier program. She has also served as a visiting professor and lecturer at numerous institutions, including Yale University, the University of Michigan, the University of Chicago, and Harvard University.
Morrison currently resides in the Hudson Valley of New York State.

scopecontent.p: The material described in this finding aid consists of manuscripts, drafts, galleys, and proofs of Morrison's novels; personal correspondence; editorial files relating to Morrison's work at Random House and later publication of two posthumous works by Toni Cade Bambara; and academic and teaching files, particularly pertaining to SUNY Albany and Princeton University. Other material from the collection, including drafts of non-fiction, theatrical, and children's literature, office working files, published books, press clippings, photographs, audiovisual materials, awards and memorabilia will be added as processing is completed.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research. Toni Morrison's manuscript material, including drafts, typescripts, galleys, and proofs found in boxes 1-11; 13-19; 22-29; 32-47; 50-56; 59-62; and 64-66 are available only via digital access in the reading room.
Some of this material is stored off site. Please allow 24-48 hrs for retrieval.

phystech.p: Some material in this collection, particularly found in Series 1: Writings and Series 2: Correspondence, was damaged by the fire that destroyed Morrison's upstate New York home in 1993. Damage ranges from charred edges to pages missing significant portions or rendered illegible.

userestrict.p: Single photocopies may be made for research purposes. No further photoduplication of copies of material in the collection can be made when Princeton University Library does not own the original. Permission to publish material from the collection must be requested from the Associate University Librarian for Rare Books and Special Collections. The library has no information on the status of literary rights in the collection and researchers are responsible for determining any questions of copyright.

appraisal.p: Nothing was removed from the collection during 2015-2016 processing.

relatedmaterial.p: Other materials relating to Toni Morrison's work at Random House may be found in the Random House records at Columbia University's Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: Identification of specific item; Date (if known); Toni Morrison Papers, Box and Folder Number; Department of Rare Books and Special Collections, Princeton University Library.

processinfo.p: Some materials in this collection were treated for fire damage and encapsulated in mylar in 1994.
This collection was processed by Allison Hughes in 2015-2016. Finding aid written by Allison Hughes in 2016.

arrangement.p: This series is arranged into subseries by genre. Currently, all material relating to Morrison's novels are available; other subseries relating to her non-fiction, children's literature, dramatic works, and other writings will be added as they are processed.

scopecontent.p: Consists of research material, notes, outlines, drafts, galleys, and proofs. Yellow legal notepads contain notes, early draft material, and inserts for later typed and printed versions. Notepads are identified by their first lines, though a single notepad may contain a variety of material, including material relating to other works, correspondence drafts, and other unrelated notes. Corrected typescript and printout drafts often show significant revisions. Material from various stages of the publication process is present, including setting copies with copy-editor's and typesetter's marks, galleys, page proofs, F&Gs (folded-and-gathered pages, in signatures but not yet bound), blueline proofs ("confirmation blues"), advance copies (bound uncorrected proofs, pre-publication, often used for book reviewers) and production/design material with page and dust-jacket samples. Page numbers are noted for paginated material
All of Morrison's novels except Song of Solomon are represented (this material was likely destroyed in the 1993 fire).
For the short story "Two of Eves," an early version of The Bluest Eye, see Subseries 2: Short Fiction.

accessrestrict.p: Toni Morrison has required the Library to make surrogate copies of all of her manuscripts (including typescripts and proofs) and diaries (appointment books), including but not restricted to those damaged by fire in 1993. This is for conservation reasons, to prevent damage and deterioration by repeated use. Researchers are required to use digital surrogates in the reading room of the Department of Rare Books and Special Collections.

scopecontent.p: Consists primarily of personal correspondence sent to Morrison's home. Professional correspondence found Morrison's office working files and fan mail are not yet available.

did.unittitle: Clinton, Bill and Hillary--White House Invitations
Cooper, Bill, Clarissa, Ashley and Courtney

scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence with Alan Rinzler and Ellin K. Roberts about The Bluest Eye; correspondence related to Morrison's position as a textbook editor at L.W. Singer Company; correspondence from Green & Hillman lawyers about a Song of Solomon movie deal and interview with the American Audio Prose Library; and correspondence with Donald McKayle, Capitol Rep Theatre, Gilbert Moses, and others regarding Dreaming Emmett.

did.unittitle: Muldoon, Paul and Jean Hanff Korelitz

scopecontent.p: Consists of memos and correspondence, contracts, publicity material and press clippings relating to projects Morrison worked on as an editor at Random House. Includes typescript material from The Greatest: My Own Story by Muhammad Ali, "Little Man, Little Man: A Children's Story" by James Baldwin, various works by Toni Cade Bambara, Angela Davis: An Autobiography, and They Came Before Columbus by Ivan Van Sertima.

did.unittitle: Series 4: Toni Cade Bambara Posthumous Publications

scopecontent.p: Drafts, proofs, and publication material relating to two works by Bambara edited and published posthumously by Morrison: Deep Sightings and Rescue Missions: Fiction, Essays, and Conversations (1996) and Those Bones Are Not My Child (working title: Ground Cover) (1999).
Photocopied typescript and computer printouts, with corrections. Folder 5 includes a note from Nara Nahm at Pantheon Books, dated June 12, 1996.

arrangement.p: This series is arranged into three subseries following the original groupings of the material.

scopecontent.p: SUNY Albany and Princeton University material consists of administrative files. Teaching files include all material relating to courses taught by Morrison at SUNY Albany, Princeton, and the University of Chicago, as well as both academic and administrative files from the Atelier program Morrison ran at Princeton.

accessrestrict.p: This material is stored off site. Please allow 24-48 hrs for retrieval.

scopecontent.p: Consists of files relating to Morrison's position as Albert Schweitzer Professor of the Humanities, which she held from 1984 to 1988, including administrative memos and database printouts, material concerning the Birth of Black Cinema conference she co-sponsored, and files concerning the post-graduate Schweitzer Humanities Fellows, Elmaz Abinader and Charlotte Nekola.

accessrestrict.p: This material is closed until 2061.
This material is closed until 2061.

scopecontent.p: Consists of files relating to Morrison's position as the Robert E. Goheen Professor in the Council of Humanities, which she held from 1989 to 2006, including administrative and departmental files as well as other events and projects.

accessrestrict.p: This subseries is temporarily closed pending review for restricted materials.

scopecontent.p: Course material includes notes, lectures, syllabi, annotated readings, and course packets. Atelier files include material relating to the administration of the interdisciplinary program and correspondence with instructors. Studies in American Africanism files include an unpublished manuscript drawn from the lectures given as part of this course.
